{{EngvarB|date=August 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2014}} {{Infobox football biography | name = Victor Wanyama | image = Victor Wanyama 20170820.jpg | image_size = 200 | caption = Wanyama playing for [[Tottenham Hotspur F.C.|Tottenham Hotspur]] in 2017 | fullname = Victor Mugubi Wanyama<ref>{{cite web |title=List of players under written contract transferred between 01/07/2016 and 31/07/2016 |url=http://www.thefa.com/-/media/files/thefaportal/governance-docs/registrations/player-registration---july-2016.ashx |publisher=The Football Association |format=PDF |page=37 |accessdate=16 February 2018}}</ref> | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1991|6|25|df=y}}<ref name="V. Wanyama">{{cite web|title=Victor Wanyama|url=http://www.goal.com/en/people/kenya/57998/victor-wanyama|publisher=Goal.com|accessdate=12 February 2015}}</ref> | birth_place = [[Nairobi]], Kenya | height = 1.88 m<ref>{{cite web |title=Victor Wanyama |url=http://www.soccerbase.com/players/player.sd?player_id=58053 |publisher=Soccerbase |accessdate=23 September 2018}}</ref> | position = [[Midfielder#Defensive midfielder|Defensive midfielder]] | currentclub = [[Tottenham Hotspur F.C.|Tottenham Hotspur]] | clubnumber = 12 | youthyears1 = 2006–2008 | youthyears2 = 2006 | youthyears3 = 2006–2007 | youthyears4 = 2007–2008 | youthclubs1 = JMJ Youth Academy | youthclubs2 = [[Nairobi City Stars]] | youthclubs3 = [[AFC Leopards]] | youthclubs4 = [[Helsingborgs IF|Helsingborg]] | years1 = 2008–2011 | clubs1 = [[Beerschot AC|Beerschot]] | caps1 = 51 | goals1 = 2 | years2 = 2011–2013 | clubs2 = [[Celtic F.C.|Celtic]] | caps2 = 61 | goals2 = 10 | years3 = 2013–2016 | clubs3 = [[Southampton F.C.|Southampton]] | caps3 = 85 | goals3 = 4 | years4 = 2016– | clubs4 = [[Tottenham Hotspur F.C.|Tottenham Hotspur]] | caps4 = 59 | goals4 = 5 | nationalyears1 = 2007– | nationalteam1 = [[Kenya national football team|Kenya]] | nationalcaps1 = 52 | nationalgoals1 = 5 | pcupdate = 16:26, 10 February 2019 (UTC) | ntupdate = 14 October 2018 }}
'''Victor Mugubi Wanyama''' ({{IPA-all|wɑˈɲɑːmɑ|[[Kenyan English]]:|Victor Mugubi Wanyama.ogg}}; born 25 June 1991) is a Kenyan professional [[association football|footballer]] who plays as a [[Midfielder#Defensive midfielder|defensive midfielder]] for [[Premier League]] club [[Tottenham Hotspur F.C.|Tottenham Hotspur]] and captains the [[Kenya national football team|Kenyan national team]].<ref name="Captain">{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/23267053 |title=Celtic's Victor Wanyama has joined Southampton, say Kenyans |work=BBC Sport |date=11 July 2013 |accessdate=20 September 2014 }}</ref>
Wanyama became the first ever Kenyan player to score in the [[UEFA Champions League]] when he scored the first goal in [[Celtic F.C.|Celtic]]'s 2–1 win over [[FC Barcelona|Barcelona]] on 7 November 2012.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.fifa.com/world-match-centre/news/newsid/224/652/3/ |title=Wanyama: Saints' sights on Europe |work=FIFA |date=17 December 2013 |accessdate=20 September 2014 }}</ref> On 11 July 2013, Wanyama moved to Premier League club [[Southampton F.C.|Southampton]] for £12.5 million making him the most expensive player sold by a Scottish club, surpassing the £9.5 million Russian club [[FC Spartak Moscow|Spartak Moscow]] paid for [[Aiden McGeady]] in 2010.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.fifa.com/world-match-centre/nationalleagues/nationalleague=england-premier-league-2000000000/news/newsid/213/511/7/index.html |title=Southampton in record swoop for Wanyama |work=FIFA |date=11 July 2013 |accessdate=20 September 2014 }}</ref>
He has earned over 50 caps for the [[Kenya national football team|Kenyan national team]] since making his international debut in May 2007 at the age of 15.
== Early life == Wanyama attended Kamukunji High School, which fields a successful football team. Upon leaving High School, he also played with JMJ Academy for three years during which time he also joined [[Kenyan Premier League]] clubs [[Nairobi City Stars]] and [[AFC Leopards]].<ref name=Cement>[http://www.standardmedia.co.ke/sports/InsidePage.php?id=2000000305&cid=38&story=Mugabe%20wants%20to%20cement%20position%20in%20Belgium%20club Mugabe wants to cement position in Belgium club] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304132405/http://www.standardmedia.co.ke/sports/InsidePage.php?id=2000000305&cid=38&story=Mugabe%20wants%20to%20cement%20position%20in%20Belgium%20club |date=4 March 2016 }} Standard Digital, 5 January 2010</ref> In 2007, he joined [[Allsvenskan]] club [[Helsingborgs IF|Helsingborg]] but after the departure of his brother [[McDonald Mariga]] to [[Serie A]] side [[Parma F.C.|Parma]] in 2008, Wanyama returned to Kenya.
== Club career ==
=== Beerschot AC === After a successful trial, Wanyama signed for [[K. Beerschot AC|Beerschot AC]] on a four-year contract in summer 2008. He made his debut in a League match at the end of the [[2008–09 Belgian First Division|2008–09 season]]. In September 2009, he was fined €100 and given a three-match suspension for a violent tackle on [[Matías Suárez]] of [[R.S.C. Anderlecht|Anderlecht]].<ref>[http://www.footgoal.net/suite.php?selection=44838 Wanyama suspendu trois matchs (Wanyama suspended three games)] {{webarchive|url=https://www.webcitation.org/6AV6dTJkR?url=http://www.footgoal.net/suite.php?selection=44838 |date=7 September 2012 }} Footgoal, 29 September 2009 {{fr icon}}</ref>
In the summer of 2010 [[Scottish Premier League]] club [[Celtic F.C.|Celtic]] attempted to sign Wanyama but Beerschot did not allow him to leave. Russian club [[CSKA Moscow]] also attempted to sign him, but they failed as well.<ref>[http://www.footgoal.net/suite.php?selection=57331 Wanyama va rester au Germinal Beerschot (Wanyama stays with Germinal Beerschot)] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100819044505/http://www.footgoal.net/suite.php?selection=57331 |date=19 August 2010 }} Footgoal, 16 April 2010 {{fr icon}}</ref>
Wanyama scored his first goal for Beerschot on 11 December 2010, a 77th-minute equaliser against Westerlo. In April 2011, he received another three match suspension after video evidence showed he had elbowed Brecht Dejaeghere of [[K.V. Kortrijk]].<ref>[http://www.footgoal.net/suite.php?selection=67175 Wanyama poursuivi (Wanyama continued)] {{webarchive|url=https://www.webcitation.org/6AV6iiuF7?url=http://www.footgoal.net/suite.php?selection=67175 |date=7 September 2012 }} Footgoal, 18 April 2011 {{fr icon}}</ref>
=== Celtic === [[File:Victor Wanyama 2012.jpg|thumb|right|upright|Wanyama playing for [[Celtic F.C.|Celtic]] in 2012]]
On 9 July 2011, Wanyama finally completed a £900,000 move to Celtic, after the Scottish club had failed to sign him the previous year.<ref name="Celtic">{{cite news |url = http://www.celticfc.net/newsstory?item=1253 |title = Wanyama is a Celt |publisher = Celtic FC |date = 9 July 2011 |accessdate = 9 July 2011 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20110817004244/http://www.celticfc.net/newsstory?item=1253 |archivedate = 17 August 2011 |df = dmy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Victor Wanyama wins work permit appeal to sign for Celtic |url=http://www.scotzine.com/2011/07/victor-wanyama-wins-work-permit-appeal-to-sign-for-celtic/ |publisher=Scotzine.com |date=8 July 2011 | accessdate=24 January 2013 }}</ref> He signed a four-year contract and in doing so became the first ever Kenyan to play in the SPL. Wanyama chose 67 as his squad number to honour the [[Lisbon Lions]], Celtic's [[1967 European Cup Final|1967 European Cup]]-winning team.<ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.eveningtimes.co.uk/sport/editor-s-picks/stipe-pletikosa-and-victor-wanyama-set-to-make-celtic-bow-1.1113107 | title = Stipe Pletikosa and Victor Wanyama set to make Celtic bow | publisher = Herald & Times Group | work = Evening Times | date = 20 July 2011 | accessdate = 23 September 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url = https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/14082372 | title = Germinal's Victor Wanyama completes switch to Celtic | publisher = BBC Sport | date = 9 July 2011 | accessdate = 25 June 2012}}</ref> Wanyama made his Celtic league debut in a 1–0 loss to [[St Johnstone F.C.|St Johnstone]] on 21 August 2011. He played in central defence rather than his favoured central midfield role.<ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.heraldscotland.com/sport/spl/celtic/when-they-scored-the-fans-wanted-more-and-we-couldn-t-handle-it-1.1119214 | title = 'When they scored the fans wanted more and we couldn't handle it’ | publisher = Herald & Times Group | work = Herald Scotland | date = 23 August 2011 | accessdate = 30 August 2011}}</ref> He came on as a late substitute in a 4–0 win over [[Motherwell F.C.|Motherwell]],<ref>{{cite news | url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/14773073.stm | title = Celtic 4–0 Motherwell | publisher = BBC Sport | date = 10 September 2011 | accessdate = 23 September 2011}}</ref> and played for the whole second half in a 2–0 [[Scottish League Cup|League Cup]] win over [[Ross County F.C.|Ross County]].<ref>{{cite news | url = http://uk.eurosport.yahoo.com/21092011/63/ross-county-v-celtic-21-september.html | title = Ross County v Celtic – 21 September | publisher = Yahoo! Sport | work = Eurosport | date = 21 September 2011 | accessdate = 23 September 2011}}</ref> On 29 September 2011, he started in Celtic's 1–1 draw with Italian team [[Udinese Calcio|Udinese]] in the [[Europa League]]. This was his first European match for the club.<ref>{{cite news | url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/15014638.stm | title = Celtic 1–1 Udinese | publisher = BBC Sport | date = 29 September 2011 | accessdate = 29 September 2011}}</ref> On 10 December 2011, Wanyama scored his first goal for Celtic in a 1–0 win over [[Heart of Midlothian F.C.|Hearts]] at [[Celtic Park]], a tremendous 25-yard strike which hit the top corner.<ref>{{cite news | url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/16015615.stm | title = Celtic 1–0 Hearts | publisher = BBC Sport | date = 10 December 2011 | accessdate = 12 December 2011}}</ref> His performances during December earned him the [[Scottish Premier League monthly awards|Scottish Premier League young player of the month]] award.<ref>{{cite news | url = http://sport.stv.tv/football/scottish-premier/celtic/293525-celtics-victor-wanyama-named-spl-young-player-of-the-month/ | title = Celtic's Victor Wanyama named SPL Young Player of the Month | publisher = STV Sport | date = 13 January 2012 | accessdate = 8 February 2012}}</ref> He scored his second Celtic goal on 2 January 2012 in a 3–0 win against Dunfermline at [[East End Park]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/16331432.stm|title=Dunfermline 0 – 3 Celtic|publisher=BBC Sport|date=2 January 2011|accessdate=3 January 2011}}</ref> Wanyama scored in Celtic's 2–1 win against [[Dundee United F.C.|Dundee United]] at [[Celtic Park]]<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2012/jan/14/hearts-hibs-celtic-aberdeen-spl|title=Celtic's Gary Hooper and Victor Wanyama strike to sink Dundee United|last=Briggs|first=Nial|work=The Guardian|date=14 January 2012}}</ref> and in the 4–0 victory against [[Hearts F.C.|Hearts]] at [[Tynecastle Stadium|Tynecastle]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/teams/celtic/9069307/Hearts-0-Celtic-4-match-report.html|title=Hearts 0 Celtic 4: match report|last=Forsyth|first=Roddy|work=The Daily Telegraph|date=8 February 2012}}</ref>
On 20 October 2012, Wanyama scored twice against [[St Mirren F.C.|St Mirren]] at [[St Mirren Park]], the second of which was a half volley from 25 yards out.<ref>{{cite news |title=Clinical Celtic warmed up for the Nou Camp with what turned out to be little more than a training exercise as they outclassed a feeble St Mirren |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/19939572 |work=BBC Sport |publisher=British Broadcasting Corporation |date=20 October 2012 |accessdate=24 January 2013 }}</ref> On 25 October, Wanyama's agent released a statement saying that he had turned down an improved contract offer from [[Celtic F.C.|Celtic]], stating that his wage demands could not be met by the club amid speculation of interest from clubs in England.<ref>{{cite news |title=Scottish Football – Wanyama rejects Celtic deal |url=http://uk.eurosport.yahoo.com/news/scottish-football-wanyama-rejects-celtic-deal-185103875.html |work=Eurosport |publisher=[[Yahoo!]] |date=25 October 2012 |accessdate=26 October 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130128003423/http://uk.eurosport.yahoo.com/news/scottish-football-wanyama-rejects-celtic-deal-185103875.html |archivedate=28 January 2013 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> On 7 November, Wanyama opened the scoring with a powerful header as [[Celtic F.C.|Celtic]] shocked [[FC Barcelona|Barcelona]] in the [[UEFA Champions League|Champions League]] group stage, by beating them 2–1 at [[Celtic Park]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.uefa.com/news/newsid=1855396.html |title=Debutant Watt lights up memorable Celtic victory |work=UEFA |date=25 October 2012 |accessdate=20 September 2014 }}</ref>
=== Southampton === [[File:Victor Wanyama 2014.jpg|thumb|right|Wanyama with [[Southampton F.C.|Southampton]] in 2014]]
After much speculation and a previous breakdown in talks, on 11 July 2013, Wanyama signed for [[Premier League]] side [[Southampton F.C.|Southampton]] for a fee claimed to be £12.5 million,<ref>{{cite web | title= Victor Wanyama: Southampton sign Celtic midfielder for £12.5m | url= https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/22969633| publisher=BBC Sport| date=11 July 2013 | accessdate= 11 July 2013}}</ref> making him the first Kenyan to ever play in the Premier League.<ref>{{cite web | title=Wanyama makes Saints switch | url=http://www.saintsfc.co.uk/news/article/wanyama-makes-saints-switch-909448.aspx | publisher=Southampton FC | date= 11 July 2013| accessdate= 11 July 2013}}</ref>
Wanyama said: {{centred pull quote|Southampton is a good club and it has good players, so I just want to train hard and work hard to be a part of the starting XI. We'll see where that will take me. It feels great and I am happy to be here. There were other options, but Southampton is a club with ambitions so I chose to come here. I'm very grateful to be here and I'm looking forward to playing in the Premier League.}}
He made his debut on 17 August 2013, in 1–0 away win against [[West Bromwich Albion F.C.|West Bromwich Albion]].<ref>{{cite web|title=West Brom 0–1 Southampton |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/23644676 |publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=19 August 2013|date=17 August 2013}}</ref> Wanyama made 24 appearances in his first season, but injuries hindered his efforts to make much of an impact in the team.<ref>{{cite web|title=Victor Wanyama desperate for Saints to end with record breaking tally|url=http://www.dailyecho.co.uk/sport/11160909.Victor_Wanyama_desperate_for_Saints_to_end_with_record_breaking_tally/|publisher=Daily Echo|accessdate=2 November 2014|date=21 April 2014}}</ref>
Under new manager [[Ronald Koeman]], Wanyama came into his own in the 2014–15 season.<ref name="f411">{{cite web|title=Wanyama considered switch|url=http://www.football411.com/story/0,22162,14287_16580,00.html|publisher=Football 411|accessdate=2 November 2014|format=24 October 2014}}</ref> He scored his first goal for the club in a 1–0 [[2014–15 Premier League|league]] victory over [[Swansea City F.C.|Swansea City]] at the [[Liberty Stadium]] on 20 September 2014, after replacing [[James Ward-Prowse]] in the 69th minute.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/29187272 |title=Swansea 0–1 Southampton|publisher=BBC Sport |date=20 September 2014 |accessdate=20 September 2014 }}</ref> His next goal came in an 8–0 trouncing of [[Sunderland A.F.C.|Sunderland]] on 19 October 2014.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Reddy |first1=Luke |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/29580147 |title=Southampton 8 – 0 Sunderland |work=BBC Sport |date=18 October 2014 |accessdate=18 October 2014}}</ref> Wanyama would score his third goal for the Saints in spectacular fashion, a 40-yard shot after [[Eldin Jakupović]]'s poor clearance fell straight to him, in what proved to be the only goal in a win over [[Hull City A.F.C.|Hull City]].<ref>{{cite web |last1=Keegan |first1=Mike |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/29768014 |title=Hull City 0 – 1 Southampton |work=BBC Sport |date=1 November 2014 |accessdate=1 November 2014}}</ref> His performances saw him awarded the league's African Player of the Month for September,<ref name="f411" /> with him stating "It is wonderful being recognised as someone who has done well for his club."<ref name="f411" />
=== Tottenham Hotspur === [[File:Manchester United v Tottenham Hotspur, December 2016 (08).JPG|thumb|right|Wanyama ''(left)'' alongside Spurs clubmates in a league clash with [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]] in 2016]] On 23 June 2016, Premier League club [[Tottenham Hotspur F.C.|Tottenham Hotspur]] announced that they had reached an agreement with Southampton for the transfer of Wanyama,<ref>{{cite web|title=Wanyama transfer completed |url=http://www.tottenhamhotspur.com/news/victor-wanyama-transfer-completed-230616/ |publisher=tottenhamhotspur.com |date=23 June 2016 |accessdate=23 June 2016}}</ref> signing a five-year contract for a fee of £11 million.<ref>{{cite web|title=Victor Wanyama: Tottenham sign Southampton midfielder on five-year deal |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/36612577 |publisher=bbc.co.uk |date=23 June 2016 |accessdate=23 June 2016}}</ref> Wanyama had previously worked with Tottenham manager [[Mauricio Pochettino]] who brought him to Southampton in July 2013.<ref>{{cite web|title=Tottenham sign Victor Wanyama from Southampton |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/football/2016/06/23/tottenham-sign-victor-wanyama-from-southampton/ |publisher=telegraph.co.uk |date=23 June 2016 |accessdate=23 June 2016}}</ref> Wanyama scored his first goal for the club on his home debut against [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]], in the 82nd minute of a 1–0 league win for Spurs.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.foxsports.com.au/football/premier-league/tottenham-v-crystal-palace-victor-wanyama-seals-spurs-first-premier-league-win-for-20162017/news-story/107b8ea4be58f68e4437dd34b9a85b6d |title=Tottenham v Crystal Palace: Victor Wanyama seals Spurs’ first Premier League win for 2016–2017 |date=21 August 2016 |work=[[Fox Sports (Australia)|Fox Sports Australia]] |accessdate=21 August 2016}}</ref> The goal made him the 138th different player to score for the club, extending its record for the most variety of goalscorers for a single club in the Premier League.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.premierleague.com/news/78854 |title=Wanyama extends Spurs benchmark |date=23 August 2016 |publisher=[[Premier League|The Premier League]] |accessdate=28 August 2016}}</ref>
Early in the [[2017–18 Tottenham Hotspur F.C. season|2017–18]] season, Wanyama injured his knee in the match against Chelsea and was sidelined for over four months.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.goal.com/en-ke/news/victor-wanyama-hands-tottenham-hotspur-injury-boost/16wcxeabv2wl71j2bnaedvdlo3 |title= Victor Wanyama hands Tottenham Hotspur injury boost |first=Taiye |last= Taiwo |date=7 December 2017 |work= Goal.com|accessdate=19 December 2017 }}</ref> He returned to training in mid-December.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Prosser|first1=Jack|title=Tottenham midfielder Victor Wanyama returns to first team training|url=https://www.standard.co.uk/sport/football/tottenham-midfielder-victor-wanyama-returns-to-first-team-training-a3716976.html|accessdate=19 December 2017|work=Evening Standard|date=11 December 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Thomas|first1=Lyall|title=Victor Wanyama returns to Tottenham training as he steps up recovery from knee injury|url=http://www.skysports.com/football/news/11675/11166861/victor-wanyama-returns-to-tottenham-training-as-he-steps-up-recovery-from-knee-injury|publisher=Sky Sports|accessdate=19 December 2017|date=11 December 2017}}</ref> On 2 January 2018, he made his first appearance after his injury, as a substitute in the away match against [[Swansea City A.F.C.|Swansea City]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.si.com/soccer/2018/01/02/swansea-city-0-2-tottenham-hotspur-spurs-grind-out-win-dreadful-weather-conditions |title=Tottenham Grinds Out Win Over Swansea in Rainy Conditions |date=2 January 2018 |work=Sports Illustrated|accessdate=2 January 2018 }}</ref>
Wanyama picked up a knee injury in a pre-season game of the [[2018–19 Tottenham Hotspur F.C. season|2018–19 season]] against Barcelona.<ref>{{cite web |url= https://cartilagefreecaptain.sbnation.com/2018/7/26/17619850/tottenham-hotspur-news-victor-wanyama-usa-tour-injury-premier-league |title=Victor Wanyama picks up knee injury on preseason | }}</ref> He made his first start of the season two months later in the [[2018–19 EFL Cup|Carabao Cup]] game against [[Watford F.C.|Watford]] that Spurs won on penalties.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.futaa.com/article/164907/full-hour-for-wanyama-as-spurs-edge-out-watford|title=Full hour for Wanyama as Spurs edge out Watford |first= Jeff |last= Kinyanjui|date= 27 September 2018 |work=Futaa}}</ref>
== International career == Wanyama made his debut for the [[Kenya national football team|Kenyan national team]] in May 2007, aged just 15 in a friendly against [[Nigeria national football team|Nigeria]].<ref name=Cement/> He also played in all six of Kenya's [[2010 FIFA World Cup]] [[2010 FIFA World Cup qualification (CAF)|qualifiers]]. He became the [[Captain (association football)|captain]] of his national team in 2013.
=== International goals === :''As of match played 14 October 2018. Kenya score listed first, score column indicates score after each Wanyama goal.''<ref name=SW>{{Soccerway|victor-wanyama/53437}}</ref>

== Career statistics == [[File:Victor Wanyama.jpg|thumb|upright|Wanyama in Celtic colours, 2012]] {{updated|match played 13 February 2019}}.<ref name="Soccerway">{{cite web | url=https://int.soccerway.com/players/victor-wanyama/53437/ | title=V. WANYAMA Stats | publisher=Soccerway | accessdate=19 January 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.soccerbase.com/players/player.sd?player_id=58053 | title=Victor Wanyama Stats | publisher=Racing Post|work=Soccerbase | accessdate=22 October 2016}}</ref>

Total ! 51 !! 2 !! 5 !! 0 !! – !! – !! – !! – !! 56 !! 2 |- | rowspan=4 | [[Celtic F.C.|Celtic]] |- | [[2011–12 Scottish Premier League|2011–12]] | 29 || 4 || 4 || 0 || 4 || 0 || 5 || 0 || 42 || 4 |- | [[2012–13 Scottish Premier League|2012–13]] | 32 || 6 || 5 || 1 || 2 || 0 || 10 || 2 || 49 || 9 |- ! == Honours == '''Celtic''' *[[Scottish Premier League]]: [[2011–12 Scottish Premier League|2011–12]], [[2012–13 Scottish Premier League|2012–13]] *[[Scottish Cup]]: [[2012–13 Scottish Cup|2013]]
'''Individual''' *[[Scottish Premier League Yearly Awards|SPL Young Player of the Year]]: [[2012–13 in Scottish football|2012–13]] *[[Scottish Premier League monthly awards|SPL Young Player of the Month]]: [[2011-12 in Scottish football|December 2011]]
== Personal life == Wanyama comes from a sporting family. His brother [[McDonald Mariga]] is also a professional footballer,<ref>[http://www.futaa.com/football/article/mariga-confirmed-at-parma Mariga confirmed at Parma] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120304195947/http://www.futaa.com/football/article/mariga-confirmed-at-parma |date=4 March 2012 }} Futaa.com, 31 January 2012</ref><ref>[https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/17705309 Kenya's McDonald Mariga faces lengthy spell out] BBC Sport, 13 April 2012</ref> while his other brothers [[Thomas Wanyama|Thomas]] and Sylvester Wanyama are also footballers in the [[Kenyan Premier League]]. His father, Noah Wanyama, was a footballer for [[A.F.C. Leopards]] in the 1980s,<ref>[http://www.futaa.com/football/article/Noah-Wanyama-hits-the-campaign-trail Noah Wanyama hits the campaign trail] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130704232701/http://www.futaa.com/football/article/noah-wanyama-hits-the-campaign-trail |date=4 July 2013 }} Futaa.com, 18 October 2011</ref> and his sister Mercy is a professional basketball player in the USA.<ref>[http://www.michezoafrika.com/basketball/mercy-wanyama-secures-kshs.20million-scholarship-package/2550.aspx Mercy Wanyama secures Kshs.20Million scholarship package] MichezoAfrika, 6 August 2011</ref>
Wanyama is managed by [[Rob Moore (South African Entrepreneur)|ExtraTime]],<ref name=ETVic>[http://www.extratime.es/clients/14/victor-wanyama Victor Wanyama] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120701110123/http://www.extratime.es/clients/14/victor-wanyama |date=1 July 2012 }} ExtraTime</ref> and has a boot sponsorship deal with Adidas.
In 2015, Wanyama participated in the production of a short film about football in Kenya called ''Mdudu Boy'', written and directed by actress [[Ella Smith (actress)|Ella Smith]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Ellis|first1=Dawn|title=Film being made by Westcountry actor has celebrity support|url=http://www.westernmorningnews.co.uk/Film-Westcountry-actor-celebrity-support/story-26821040-detail/story.html|accessdate=5 March 2016|publisher=Western Morning News|date=2 July 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150803092543/http://www.westernmorningnews.co.uk/Film-Westcountry-actor-celebrity-support/story-26821040-detail/story.html|archive-date=3 August 2015|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
